Furthermore, good sons!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who cultivate loving-kindness, compassion, and joy can abide in the ground of utmost love and only child.
Good sons!
Why is this ground called utmost love and only child?
Good sons!
It is like parents who see their child safe and sound and are overjoyed.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who abide in this ground are also like this, regarding all sentient beings as their only child, and seeing those who cultivate goodness give rise to great joy.
Therefore, this ground is called utmost love.
Good sons!
It is like parents who see their child afflicted with illness and give rise to suffering and distress, pitying them and being sorrowful, never abandoning them.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas dwelling in this ground are also like this. Seeing sentient beings afflicted by the illnesses of afflictions, their minds give rise to sorrow and worry, regarding them like children, with blood flowing from all the pores of their bodies.
Therefore, this ground is called the One Child.
Good man!
It is like a person when young, picking up lumps of earth, filth, tiles, stones, withered bones, and twigs and putting them in their mouth.
Their parents, seeing this, fear it will harm them, and with their left hand they hold their head while with their right hand they pick it out.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas dwelling in this ground are also like this. Seeing sentient beings whose Dharma body has not yet increased, or engaging in unwholesome actions of body, speech, and mind, the bodhisattvas, seeing this, then use the hand of wisdom to pull them out, not wishing for them to flow through birth and death, experiencing various sufferings and afflictions.
Therefore, this ground is also called the One Child.
Good man!
It is like a parent's beloved child who dies, and the parents grieve and wish to die with them.
The bodhisattva is also like this. Seeing a icchantika fall into hell, he also wishes to be born in hell with them.
Why is this?

If this icchantika experiences suffering and gives rise to a single thought of repentance, I will then expound various teachings for them, enabling them to give rise to a single thought of wholesome roots.
Therefore, this stage is also called the One Child.
Good man!
It is like a parent who has only one child. They always think of that child, whether they are sleeping, awake, walking, standing, sitting, or lying down.
If the child has faults, they instruct them with kind words and do not harm them.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. Seeing sentient beings who have fallen into hell, the realm of animals, the realm of hungry ghosts, or who are creating good or evil in the realms of humans and gods, they always think of them and never abandon them.
If someone engages in evil, they will never give rise to anger or add evil to them.
Therefore, this ground is also called the ground of the only child.
Bodhisattva Kasyapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, his words are secret and profound. My wisdom is shallow now, so how can I understand?

If the bodhisattvas abide in the ground of the only child and are able to be like this, why did the Tathagata, when he was a king practicing the bodhisattva path in the past, cut off the lives of so many Brahmins?
If one attains this ground, then one should be protected and remembered;
if one does not attain it, then why did he not fall into hell?
If one regards all sentient beings equally, considering them the same as one's own child, like Rahula, why did he also say to Devadatta:
'Foolish person, without shame, eating the snot and spittle of others.
' Causing him, upon hearing this, to give rise to anger and hatred, give rise to an unwholesome mind, and draw blood from the Buddha's body?
Devadatta having committed this evil, the TathÄgata again predicted that he would fall into hell for an eon to receive punishment.
World-Honored One!
How are such words not contradictory in meaning?
World-Honored One!
SubhÅ«ti abides in the ground of emptiness. Whenever he wishes to enter a city to beg for food and drink, he must first observe people.
If there is anyone who gives rise to a hateful or jealous mind towards him, he will stop and not go, even if he is extremely hungry, he will still not go begging.
Why is this?
SubhÅ«ti always thinks like this:
I remember in the past, towards a field of merit, I gave rise to a single evil thought. Because of this cause and condition, I fell into a great hell and received various sufferings.
I would rather starve and not eat all day, I would never let them give rise to hatred towards me and fall into hell to receive suffering and distress.
He also thinks like this:
If there are sentient beings who hate me standing, I will sit upright all day without getting up;
If there are sentient beings who dislike my sitting, I will stand all day without moving.
Walking and lying down are also like this.'
SubhÅ«ti, for the sake of protecting sentient beings, still gives rise to such thoughts, let alone a bodhisattva?
If a bodhisattva attains the stage of the only child, for what reason would the TathÄgata speak such coarse words to cause sentient beings to give rise to grave evil thoughts?
Good man!
You should not make such a difficult statement, saying:
'The Buddha TathÄgata creates causes and conditions for afflictions for sentient beings.'
Good man!
Even if a mosquito's mouth could drain the bottom of the ocean, the TathÄgata would never create causes and conditions for afflictions for sentient beings.
Good man!

Even if the great earth were all to become non-form, water were to have the characteristic of dryness, fire were to have the characteristic of coolness, wind were to have the characteristic of stillness, the three jewels, Buddha-nature, and space were to have the characteristic of impermanence, the TathÄgata would never create causes and conditions for afflictions for sentient beings.
Good sons!

Even if one commits the grave offenses of the four grave prohibitions and the crime of a heinous offense, and slanders the true Dharma, if one attains the ten powers, fearlessness, the thirty-two marks, and the eighty minor characteristics of a TathÄgata in this very body, the TathÄgata will never create causes and conditions for afflictions for the sake of sentient beings.
Good sons!
Even if the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas abide permanently without change, the TathÄgata will never create causes and conditions for afflictions for the sake of sentient beings.
Good sons!

Even if the bodhisattvas of the tenth stage commit the four grave offenses, become icchantikas, and slander the true Dharma, the TathÄgata will never create causes and conditions for afflictions for the sake of sentient beings.
Good sons!

Even if all immeasurable sentient beings lose their buddha-nature and the TathÄgata ultimately enters parinirvÄá¹‡a, the TathÄgata will never create causes and conditions for afflictions for the sake of sentient beings.
Good sons!
Even if one could catch the wind with a net, break iron with teeth, or destroy Mount Sumeru with nails, the TathÄgata would never create causes for afflictions for sentient beings.
It would be better to be in the same place as a poisonous snake, put one's two hands in the mouth of a starving lion, or wash one's body with burning charcoal, but one should not say:
'The TathÄgata, the World-Honored One, creates causes for afflictions for sentient beings.'
Good man!
The TathÄgata is truly able to eliminate afflictions for sentient beings, and he never creates causes for afflictions.
Good man!
As you say:
The TathÄgata killed a brÄhman in the past.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas do not intentionally kill even ants, let alone brÄhmans.
The bodhisattva always creates various skillful means to bestow immeasurable life upon sentient beings.
Good man!
Giving food is giving life.
When Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of giving, they always give sentient beings immeasurable life spans.
Good man!
Cultivating the precept of not killing leads to a long life span.
When Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of morality, they are giving all sentient beings immeasurable life spans.
Good man!
Being careful with one's speech and avoiding faults leads to a long life span.

When Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of patience, they always encourage sentient beings not to harbor thoughts of enmity, to give others the benefit of the doubt, to take the blame upon themselves, and to avoid disputes, leading to a long life span.
Therefore, when Bodhisattvas practice the perfection of patience, they have already given sentient beings immeasurable life spans.
Good man!
Diligent cultivation of goodness leads to a long life span.
When Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of vigor, they always encourage sentient beings to diligently cultivate wholesome dharmas;
Sentient beings who practice this attain immeasurable longevity.
Therefore, when bodhisattvas practice the perfection of vigor, they have already bestowed immeasurable longevity upon sentient beings.
Good man!
Those who cultivate and concentrate the mind attain long life.
When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of meditation, they encourage sentient beings to cultivate an impartial mind;
Sentient beings who practice this attain long life.
Therefore, when bodhisattvas practice the perfection of meditation, they have already bestowed immeasurable longevity upon sentient beings.
Good man!
Those who are not negligent in wholesome dharmas attain long life.
When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of wisdom, they encourage sentient beings not to be negligent in wholesome dharmas;
Sentient beings who practice this attain long life due to this cause and condition.
Therefore, when bodhisattvas practice the perfection of wisdom, they have already bestowed immeasurable longevity upon sentient beings.
Good man!
For this reason, Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas never take the lives of any sentient beings.
Good man!
You asked before:
'When killing a Brahmin, can one attain this ground?'
Good man!
At that time, I had already attained it;
But out of love and concern, I took his life, not out of malice.
Good man!
It is like a parent who has only one child, cherishing it deeply. If the child commits an offense against the law,
The parents, out of fear, may banish or even kill the child.
Although there may be banishment or killing, there is no malice.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas protect the true Dharma in the same way. If there are sentient beings who slander the Mahayana, they will immediately whip and beat them, inflict pain on them, or even take their lives, wanting them to change their past ways and follow and cultivate wholesome dharmas.
Bodhisattvas should always contemplate like this:
'By what causes and conditions can sentient beings give rise to faith?'
I will do whatever it takes to accomplish this.
After the brÄhmans died, they were reborn in the AvÄ«ci Hell, and then had three thoughts:
First, they thought:
'From where did I come to be reborn here?'
They then knew for themselves that they had come from the human realm;
Second, they thought:
'Where have I been reborn now?'
They then knew for themselves that it was the AvÄ«ci Hell;
Third, they thought:
'By what karmic conditions did I come to be reborn here?'
They then knew for themselves that it was because they had slandered the MahÄyÄna sÅ«tras, did not believe in causes and conditions, and were killed by the ruler, that they came to be reborn here.
Having had these thoughts, they then gave rise to a mind of faith and respect towards the MahÄyÄna sÅ«tras.
They then immediately ended their lives and were reborn in the world of the TathÄgata Amá¹›tadundubhi, where they had a lifespan of ten kalpas.
Good man!
For this reason, in the past I gave this person a lifespan of ten kalpas.
What is meant by killing?
Good man!
Are there people who dig the ground, cut grass, chop trees, cut up corpses, scold and beat, who fall into hell because of these karmic actions?
Bodhisattva Kasyapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
According to my understanding of the meaning of the Buddha's teachings, one should fall into hell.
Why is it so?
As the Buddha once taught the Shravakas:
'You bhiká¹£us should not give rise to evil thoughts towards any grass or trees.
Why is it so?
Because all sentient beings fall into hell due to evil thoughts.'
At that time, the Buddha praised Bodhisattva Kasyapa, saying:
Excellent, excellent!
You should uphold it well.
Good man!
If one falls into hell due to evil thoughts, then at that time the Bodhisattva truly has no evil thoughts.
Why is it so?
Because bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas give rise to a compassionate and beneficial mind towards all sentient beings, down to insects and ants.
Why is it so?
Because they skillfully understand the various skillful means of causes and conditions, and with the power of skillful means they wish to enable sentient beings to plant various roots of goodness.
Good man!
For this reason, at that time I used skillful means to take away their lives, but it was not out of an evil mind.
Good man!
According to the brÄhmaá¹‡a's teachings, if one kills ants filling ten carts, there is no karmic retribution;
Mosquitoes, flies, fleas, lice, cats, weasels, lions, tigers, wolves, bears, and other vicious animals, as well as those that harm sentient beings, killing them to fill ten carts;

ghosts, spirits, rÄká¹£asas, kumbhÄá¹‡á¸as, piÅ›Äcas, those who are insane, withered ghosts and spirits, and so forth, who are able to harm sentient beings, and those who take away their lives, will have no retribution for their crimes.
If one kills evil people, then one will have retribution for their crimes. If one kills and does not repent, one will fall into the realm of hungry ghosts;
if one is able to repent and fast for three days, their crimes will be extinguished without remainder.
If one kills one's preceptor, harms one's parents, women, or cows, one will be in hell for countless thousands of years.
Good sons!
The Buddha and Bodhisattvas know that killing has three levels: lower, middle, and upper.
The lower level includes ants and all other animals, except for those who are born as animals by the Bodhisattvas' manifestation.
Good sons!
The Bodhisattva-MahÄsattvas, due to the causes and conditions of their vows, manifest themselves as animals. This is called the lower level of killing.
Due to the causes and conditions of killing, one falls into the hells, animal realms, and hungry ghost realms, and fully experiences the lower sufferings.
Why is this?
Because these animals have slight wholesome roots.
Therefore, the killer fully experiences the retribution of offenses, which is called the lower killing.
The middling killing refers to killing from ordinary people up to the non-returners, which is called middling.
Due to this karmic cause, one falls into the hells, animal realms, and hungry ghost realms, and fully experiences the middling sufferings, which is called the middling killing.
The superior killing refers to killing one's parents up to arhats, pratyekabuddhas, and definitely destined bodhisattvas, which is called superior.
Due to this karmic cause, one falls into the AvÄ«ci great hell and fully experiences the superior sufferings, which is called the superior killing.
Good man!
If one is able to kill an icchantika, then one does not fall into these three types of killing.
Good man!
All those brahmins are icchantikas.
It is like digging the earth, cutting grass, chopping wood, cutting up a corpse, scolding, or beating, without incurring any karmic retribution;
killing an icchantika is also like this, without incurring any karmic retribution.
Why is this?
Because those brahmins do not have the five dharmas such as faith, therefore, even if they kill, they do not fall into hell.
Good man!
You previously said:
'Why did the TathÄgata call Devadatta a foolish man who eats spittle?
' You should not ask in this way.
Why is this?
The words spoken by all Buddha-World-Honored Ones are inconceivable.
Good man!
There are true words that are loved by the world, but they are untimely, not in accordance with the Dharma, and not beneficial. I would never speak such words.
Good man!
Or if there are words that are coarse, false, untimely, unrighteous, unloved by the hearers, and not beneficial, I also do not speak them.
Good man!
If there are words that are coarse, but true and not false, timely, righteous, able to benefit all beings, and though unloved by the hearers, I will still speak them.
Why is this?
Because the Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones, the Perfectly Enlightened Ones, know skillful means.
Good man!
Once, I was wandering in the forest grove of that village,
Under the trees, there was a ghost named Khangye, who only ate flesh and blood, killed many beings, and daily ate one person in that village.
Good man!
At that time, I extensively expounded the essential Dharma for that ghost.
However, he was violent, evil, foolish, ignorant, and did not accept the teachings.
I then transformed my body into a powerful ghost, shaking his palace and making it unstable.
At that time, the ghost came out of his palace with his retinue, wanting to resist and oppose.
When the ghost saw me, he immediately lost his thoughts, fell to the ground in fear, and fainted as if dead.
I compassionately touched his body with my hand, and he immediately sat up and said:
How wonderful! Today I have regained my life.
This great god king possesses great majestic virtue and a compassionate heart, forgiving my faults.
He then gave rise to wholesome faith in me.
I then restored my body to that of the TathÄgata and further expounded various essential teachings for him, causing the ghost to accept the precept against killing.
On that very day, there was an elder in the village of KÄnana who was next in line to die.
The villagers had already sent him to the ghost.
The ghost, having obtained him, immediately offered him to me.
After I accepted it, I gave the elder a new name, calling him the Elder Hand.
At that time, the ghost said to me:
World-Honored One!
I and my retinue rely solely on blood and flesh to sustain ourselves.
Now, because of the precepts, how shall we live?
I then replied:
From now on, I will order my Å›rÄvaka disciples to provide you with food and drink wherever the Buddha's teachings are practiced.
Good man!
For this reason, I have established the following precept for the bhiká¹£us:
'From now on, you should always provide food for the ghost in the wilderness.
If there are places that cannot provide it, know that they are not my disciples, but are the retinue and followers of the celestial demon.'
Good man!
The TathÄgata, in order to subdue sentient beings, manifests various skillful means like this, not intentionally causing them to be frightened.
Good man!
I also used wood to beat the Dharma-protecting ghost.
At one time, on a mountain, I pushed the sheep-headed ghost to fall down the mountain.
I also beat the monkey-protecting ghost on the treetop, causing the wealth-protecting elephant to see five lions, and frightening the vajra spirit and Satyakaparivartaka.
I also pricked the body of the arrow-haired ghost with a needle.
Although I did this, I also did not cause those ghosts and spirits to be destroyed. I just wanted to make them abide in the true Dharma, thus demonstrating various skillful means.
Good man!
At that time, I really did not insult Devadatta.

Devadatta is not foolish, nor does he eat people's spittle and mucus, nor is he born into an evil destiny, nor does he receive punishment for one eon in the AvÄ«ci Hell, nor does he destroy the Saá¹…gha or draw blood from the Buddha, nor does he violate the four grave offenses, slander the true Dharma, or the MahÄyÄna scriptures, nor is he a icchantika, nor is he a Å›rÄvaka or pratyekabuddha.
Good man!
Devadatta is truly not within the realm of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, but is only known and seen by the buddhas.
Good man!
Therefore, you should not now ask,
Why does the TathÄgata scold and revile Devadatta?
You should not give rise to such doubts regarding the realm of the buddhas.
Bodhisattva MahÄkÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
It is like sugarcane, which can be repeatedly boiled to obtain various flavors.

I am also like this. I have heard the Buddha's teachings many times and obtained much of the flavor of the Dharma, namely the flavor of leaving the household life, the flavor of detachment from desires, the flavor of tranquility, and the flavor of the Way.
World-Honored One!

It is just like true gold, which is repeatedly burned, struck, melted, and refined, becoming more and more bright, pure, pliable, and soft, with a subtle and wonderful luster, its value immeasurable, and then it is treasured by humans and gods.
World-Honored One!

The TathÄgata is also like this. By asking questions in detail, one gets to hear and see the profound meaning, causing those who practice deeply to uphold and practice it, and countless beings to give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment, and then they are respected, revered, and offered to by humans and gods.
At that time, the Buddha praised Bodhisattva KÄÅ›yapa, saying:
Excellent, excellent!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, in order to benefit all beings, you ask the TathÄgata about such profound meanings.
Good man!
For this reason, I will follow your intention and speak of the Mahayana Vaipulya profound and secret Dharma, namely the stage of utmost love like a single child.
Bodhisattva Kasyapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
If the bodhisattvas cultivate loving-kindness, compassion, and joy and attain the stage of a single child, then when cultivating the mind of equanimity, what stage do they attain again?
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
You know the time well, and when I wish to speak, you then inquire.
When the bodhisattva-mahasattva cultivates the mind of equanimity, he then abides in the stage of emptiness and equality, like Subhuti.
Good man!

When the bodhisattva-mahasattva abides in the stage of emptiness and equality, he does not see parents, brothers, sisters, children, relatives, acquaintances, enemies, or ordinary people, and does not even see the aggregates, realms, sense bases, sentient beings, or life.
Good man!
It is like empty space, which has no parents, brothers, wives, children, or even sentient beings or life.
All dharmas are also like this, having no parents, up to and including life.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas see all dharmas in this way, and their minds are impartial, like empty space.
Why is this?
Because they are well able to cultivate the dharmas of emptiness.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva KÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
What is called emptiness?
Good man!

Emptiness refers to inner emptiness, outer emptiness, inner and outer emptiness, conditioned emptiness, unconditioned emptiness, beginningless emptiness, intrinsic emptiness, emptiness of non-existence, ultimate emptiness, emptiness of emptiness, and great emptiness.
How do bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate inner emptiness?
These bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate the emptiness of internal phenomena.

This is the emptiness of internal phenomena, referring to the absence of parents, enemies, friends, neutral people, sentient beings, life, permanence, bliss, self, purity, the TathÄgata, the Dharma, the Saá¹ƒgha, and all possessions.
Although the Buddha-nature exists within these internal phenomena, the Buddha-nature is neither internal nor external.
Why is this?
Because the Buddha-nature abides permanently, without change.
This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's contemplation of internal emptiness.
External emptiness is also like this, with no internal phenomena.
The emptiness of both internal and external is also like this.
Good son!
Only the TathÄgata, the Dharma, the Saá¹ƒgha, and the Buddha-nature are not included in the two kinds of emptiness.
Why is this?
Because these four dharmas are permanent, blissful, self, and pure.
Therefore, the four dharmas are not called empty.
This is called the emptiness of both internal and external.
Good son!

As for the emptiness of conditioned phenomena, conditioned phenomena are all empty, namely, the emptiness of the internal, the emptiness of the external, the emptiness of the internal and external, the emptiness of permanence, bliss, self, and purity, the emptiness of sentient beings, life, the TathÄgata, the Dharma, the Saá¹ƒgha, and the ultimate truth.
Among them, buddha-nature is not a conditioned phenomenon.
Therefore, buddha-nature is not empty of conditioned phenomena.
This is called the emptiness of conditioned phenomena.
Good sons!
How do bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate the emptiness of unconditioned phenomena?

These unconditioned phenomena are all empty, namely, the absence of impermanence, suffering, impurity, self, the aggregates, realms, sense bases, the characteristics of sentient beings and life, the conditioned, the contaminated, internal phenomena, and external phenomena.
Within unconditioned phenomena, the four dharmas such as the Buddha are neither conditioned nor unconditioned.
Because their nature is good, they are not unconditioned;
Because their nature abides permanently, they are not conditioned.
This is called the bodhisattvas' contemplation of the emptiness of unconditioned phenomena.
What is meant by bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplating the emptiness of beginninglessness?
These bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas see that birth and death are beginningless, all empty and quiescent.
As for what is empty, permanence, bliss, self, and purity are all empty and quiescent, without change - sentient beings, life, the Three Jewels, buddha-nature, and unconditioned dharmas.
This is called bodhisattvas contemplating the emptiness of beginninglessness.
What is meant by bodhisattvas contemplating the emptiness of nature?

These bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate all dharmas as originally empty by nature, referring to the aggregates, realms, and sense bases, permanence and impermanence, suffering and bliss, purity and impurity, self and non-self.
Contemplating such dharmas, they do not see their original nature. This is called bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplating the emptiness of nature.
What is meant by bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplating the emptiness of non-existence?
It is like a person without children saying their house is empty.
Ultimately contemplating emptiness, there is no affection.

Foolish people say that the directions are empty, and poor people say that everything is empty. Such conceptions may be empty or not empty. When bodhisattvas contemplate, it is like poor people who are all empty.
This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's contemplation of the emptiness of non-existence.
What is the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's contemplation of the emptiness of the ultimate truth?
Good man!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate the ultimate truth, when the eye is born, it does not come from anywhere, and when it ceases, it does not go anywhere. It did not exist before, but now it does. After it exists, it returns to non-existence. Investigating its true nature, there is no eye, and no owner of the eye.
Like the eye, all dharmas are also like this.
What is called the emptiness of the ultimate truth?
There is karma, and there are karmic retributions, but no doer is seen. Such empty dharmas are called the emptiness of the ultimate truth.
This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's contemplation of the emptiness of the ultimate truth.
What is the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's contemplation of the emptiness of emptiness?
This emptiness within emptiness is the place where Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas become confused and submerged.

Even the bodhisattvas of the tenth stage can only partially penetrate this, like a tiny particle, let alone other people.

When I now speak such meanings of emptiness in this great assembly, there are bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas equal to the sands of ten Ganges Rivers who immediately attain to abide in the ground equal to space.
Good sons!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who abide in this ground are unhindered, bound, or attached to any phenomena, and their minds are free from confusion.

Good sons!
It is just as space, when encountering a pleasant form, does not give rise to craving attachment, and when encountering an unpleasant form, does not give rise to anger.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas abiding in this ground are also like this, with no craving or anger towards good or bad forms.

It is just as space is vast and unobstructed, able to contain all phenomena.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas abiding in this ground are also like this, vast and unobstructed, able to contain all phenomena.

Whether it is practice, conditions, nature, characteristics, causes, conditions, the minds of sentient beings, faculties, meditative absorptions, vehicles, good and virtuous friends, upholding precepts, or giving, they know and see all such dharmas.

They know the methods of self-starvation, drowning in a pond, jumping into a fire, falling from a high cliff, always standing on one leg, scorching the body with five fires;
